titleStmt.title: An entry from the Journals of Hensley Henson

sourceDesc.bibl: Edited from the manuscripts in the custody of Durham Cathedral Library.

p.hi: I left Winchester at 9.16 a.m., & arrived in Oxford at 11.8 a.m. After lunching with the Vice–Chancellor,
I officiated at the Funeral of
Mary's, finally at Wolvercote cemetery. There was a considerable muster of dons, in spite of the fact that the University had gone down.

I travelled to Paddington by the train leaving Oxford at 4.30 p.m. After leaving my bags in Park Lane, I went to the Athenaeum, where I found
, with whom I talked about the Archbishop's resignation. He agreed with me that the Church's interest and the Archbishop's reputation are both injured by the postponement of his Grace's resignation.
I gathered that the general impression made by the Archbishop's speech in the Assembly was that the Church intends to take its recent experiences "lying down"!

, & several others were there. I was particularly interested in the account of the emancipation of the slaves & prohibition of human sacrifices among the animistic tribes in India given by a very fat man, who was the official who actually carried the business through.

He said that most of the "Congo atrocities" were manufactured in Cape Town. The more one gets "behind the scenes", and observes the actual processes by which "History" is made, the more sceptical one becomes. And how little of the known facts are suffered to be recorded or made known.
